Java Error: Cannot make a static reference to the non-static field or method

April 19, 2017

I was working on my project and wanted to test it, so I thought the easiest way would be to create a public static void main method in it as follows.

package alignmentparser;

import java.util.Scanner;

public class AlignmentFileParser {
    private static Scanner sc = new Scanner(System.in);

    public void uploadAlignmentFile() {
        System.out.println("Input BLAST alignment file path: ");
        String s = sc.nextLine();
        System.out.println(s);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        uploadAlignmentFile();
    }
}

But when I run that, I get the error

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.Error: Unresolved compilation problem: 
    Cannot make a static reference to the non-static method uploadAlignmentFile() from the type AlignmentFileParser

    at alignmentparser.AlignmentFileParser.main(AlignmentFileParser.java:15)

In Java you have instance members (variables and methods) and static members. Instance members are variables and methods that you can only access when you have an instance of a class.

So the only way to call a non-static method ANYWHERE is to have an instance of the class. You cannot call non-static methods or access non-static fields from main or any other static method, because non-static members belong to a class instance, not to the entire class.

So I could fix it as follows:

public static void main(String[] args) {
    AlignmentFileParser parser = new AlignmentFileParser(); 
    parser.uploadAlignmentFile();
}

But since I asked myself “does it make sense to call this method, even if no Obj has been constructed yet?” It does, so I decided to only fix the public void uploadAlignmentFile to static.
